{{Infobox university | name = Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences | image = | alt = | caption = | motto = | location = 68-B, New Muslim Town, Lahore, [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]] | country = [[Pakistan]] | coordinates = {{Coord|31.513142|74.314912|type:edu_region:PK|display=title}} | pushpin_map = Pakistan | type = Research Institute | established = {{Start date|2003}} | website = {{URL|www.sms.edu.pk}} | affiliation = [[Government College University, Lahore|Government College University Lahore]] (GCU Lahore) }}
The '''Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences''' (AS-SMS) is an autonomous institute affiliated with the [[Government College University Lahore]], [[Pakistan]].<ref name="The Government College University Official website ">{{Cite web|last=(GCU) |first=Government College University |authorlink=Government College University, Lahore |coauthors= |title=Science Research at GCU: The Abdus Salam School of Mathematics |work= |publisher=The Government College University Official website |url=http://www.gcu.edu.pk/ASSMS.htm |doi= |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121016190004/http://gcu.edu.pk/ASSMS.htm |archivedate=2012-10-16 }}</ref> The school is named after the [[theoretical physicist]] and [[Nobel Laureate]] [[Abdus Salam]].
==History== [[Abdus Salam]] played an influential role in formulating policies for the development of science in Pakistan in the late 1960s and early 1970s. He helped establish a number of research institutes in Pakistan including the [[Pakistan Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology]] (PINSTECH) and the Atomic Energy Commission.
In 2003, the [[Government of Punjab, Pakistan|Government of Punjab]] established a center of excellence in mathematical sciences, the School of Mathematical Sciences, affiliated with Government College University, Lahore.<ref name="The Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences Official website">{{Cite web | last =ASSMS | first =The Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Achievements | work = | publisher =The Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences Official website | url =http://www.sms.edu.pk/?page_id=1176 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 30 September 2016}}</ref> The idea behind the school is to create a world-class doctoral research institute in mathematics, but rooted in a developing country like Pakistan.<ref name="GC University Lahore Prospectus 2014 ">{{cite web|url=http://www.gcu.edu.pk/Forms/ProspectusBA-M.Phil/2014/83-92.pdf |title=Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences |publisher=GC University Lahore |accessdate=18 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924021111/http://www.gcu.edu.pk/Forms/ProspectusBA-M.Phil/2014/83-92.pdf |archivedate=24 September 2015 }}</ref><ref name="A Report of ASSMS">{{cite web | url= http://sms.edu.pk/downloads/phd/areportonassms.pdf | title=A Report of ASSMS | publisher= Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences | accessdate=18 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504062917/http://www.sms.edu.pk/downloads/phd/areportonassms.pdf |archivedate=May 4, 2015}}</ref> The school was later named after Abdus Salam who was professor of mathematics at the Government College (Lahore) from 1951 to 1954.
[[File:Dinnervc.jpg|thumb|[[Ghulam Murtaza (physicist)|Ghulam Murtaza]] (second from left), [[:de:Gerhard Pfister (Mathematiker)|Gerhard Pfister]] (fourth from left), Chairman of The Board of Governors (third from right), [[Amer Iqbal]] (second from right), and other faculty members.]]
Ghulam Murtaza, an eminent physicist who held the Abdus Salam Chair at Government College University, was appointed the first Director-General of the school. The second Director-General was Alla Ditta Raza Choudary, an emeritus professor from [[Central Washington University]]. The third director general of the school was Shahid Saeed Siddiqi, who was a professor of mathematics at the [[University of the Punjab|Punjab University]]. Since March 2017 the director general of the school is again Ghulam Murtaza who also holds the [[Abdus Salam Chair in Physics]] at the Government College University (Lahore).
==Program overview== [[File:Abdus Salam School.jpg|thumb|Foreign Faculty Tiberiu Dumitrescu and [[:ro:Ioan Tomescu|Ioan Tomescu]] ([[University of Bucharest|Bucharest]]) with doctorands at the Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences]]ASSMS requires an intensive two-year course for all the students admitted. The first year is dedicated to basic university mathematics course, and in the second year students take more advanced and optional courses in diverse areas of mathematics. At the end of their second year, students choose one of the research groups at AS-SMS, which are geometry, algebra, analysis, discrete mathematics, applied mathematics, and stochastic processes.<ref name="Editorial in Newsletter of European Mathematical Society about ASSMS">{{cite journal|last=Laudal|first=Arnfinn|date=June 2011|title=Editorial: Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences|url=https://www.ems-ph.org/journals/newsletter/pdf/2011-06-80.pdf|journal=Newsletter of European Mathematical Society|publisher=EMS Publishing House|issue=80|pages=3–4|access-date=September 26, 2016}}</ref> The graduation rate at the end of fifth year is high.<ref name="Article about ASSMS by Loring W. Tu in the Notices of the American Mathematical Society">{{cite journal|last=Tu|first=Loring|date=August 2011|title=The Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences in Lahore|url=https://www.ams.org/notices/201107/rtx110700938p.pdf|journal=Notices of the American Mathematical Society|publisher=American Mathematical Society|volume=58|issue=7|pages=938–943|access-date=September 26, 2016}}</ref>
The institution provides free-of-cost education to its students. It also provides financial assistance to its students.<ref name="GC University Lahore Prospectus 2014 "/>
==Achievements== [[File:Abdus Salam School 2.jpg|thumb|[[János Pach]], Edy T. Baskoro ([[Bandung Institute of Technology|ITB]]), [[:ro:Ioan Tomescu|Ioan Tomescu]] and students at a conference in the school.]] Since its inception until early 2014, AS-SMS has produced more than 100 Ph.D. This is more than twice the total number of Ph.Ds in mathematics produced by all other universities in Pakistan in the same period.<ref name="ASSMS Lahore conferred the 100th Ph.D">{{cite journal | last1=Laudal | first1=Arnfinn |last2=Sanz-Solé |first2=Marta |last3=Waldschmidt |first3=Michel|date=March 2014 | title=A Mathematical Anniversary in Pakistan| journal=Newsletter of European Mathematical Society |issue=91 | pages=8–9 |publisher=EMS Publishing House |url=https://www.ems-ph.org/journals/newsletter/pdf/2014-03-91.pdf|access-date=September 26, 2016}}</ref> It has produced more than 800 publications in [[Institute for Scientific Information|ISI]]-indexed journals.<ref name="GC University Lahore Prospectus 2014 "/>
AS-SMS has organized several international level workshops and conferences. Some of workshops at ASSMS has been chosen to have funding from the [[ICTP]], [[UNESCO]], and CIMPA (International Centre for Pure and Applied Mathematics). The signature conferences of ASSMS are its “World/International Conferences of Mathematics in the 21st Century” series, which has been held in 2004,<ref name="World Conference in 21st Century Mathematics">{{cite web|url=http://www.wc2004.sms.edu.pk/ |title=1st World Conference in 21st Century Mathematics |publisher=Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences |accessdate=18 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040506084642/http://www.wc2004.sms.edu.pk/ |archivedate=May 6, 2004 }}</ref> 2005,<ref name="The 2nd World Conference in 21st Century Mathematics">{{cite web|url=http://wc2005.sms.edu.pk/ |title=2nd World Conference in 21st Century Mathematics |publisher=Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences |accessdate=18 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050209184818/http://wc2005.sms.edu.pk/ |archivedate=February 9, 2005 }}</ref> 2007,<ref name="The 3rd International Conference in 21st Century Mathematics">{{cite web|url=http://wc2007.sms.edu.pk/index.php |title=3rd International Conference in 21st Century Mathematics |publisher=Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences |accessdate=18 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060813135456/http://wc2007.sms.edu.pk/index.php |archivedate=August 13, 2006 }}</ref> 2009,<ref name="The 4th World Conference in 21st Century Mathematics">{{cite web|url=http://wc2009.sms.edu.pk/ |title=4th World Conference in 21st Century Mathematics |publisher=Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences |accessdate=18 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081107042044/http://wc2009.sms.edu.pk/ |archivedate=November 7, 2008 }}</ref> 2011,<ref name="The 5th World Conference in 21st Century Mathematics">{{cite web|url=http://wc2011.sms.edu.pk/doku.php |title=5th World Conference in 21st Century Mathematics |publisher=Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences |accessdate=18 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728112434/http://wc2011.sms.edu.pk/doku.php |archivedate=July 28, 2011 }}</ref> and 2013.<ref name="The 6th World Conference in 21st Century Mathematics">{{cite web|url=http://wc2013.sms.edu.pk/doku.php |title=6th World Conference in 21st Century Mathematics |publisher=Abdus Salam School of Mathematical Sciences |accessdate=18 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130320003932/http://wc2013.sms.edu.pk/doku.php |archivedate=March 20, 2013 }}</ref> The last conference has its proceedings published by the prestigious [[Springer Publishing]] by the title "Mathematics in the 21st Century"; with [[Pierre Cartier (mathematician)|Pierre Cartier]], A. D. R. Choudary (the then Director General of AS-SMS), and [[Michel Waldschmidt]] as the editors.<ref name="Springer Book: “Mathematics in the 21st Century" >{{cite web | url= https://www.springer.com/us/book/9783034808583 | title= Mathematics in the 21st Century | publisher= Springer | accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref>
AS-SMS was chosen as Post-Doctoral research destination from Ph.D holders from prestigious institutions around the world. Young researchers from Russia, Italy, Romania, Indonesia, and other countries have become Post Doctoral Fellows in ASSMS. This is something that not used to happen in any mathematics institution in Pakistan before the existence of ASSMS.<ref name="GC University Lahore Prospectus 2014 " /><ref name="A Report of ASSMS"/>
On the recommendation of the Committee for Developing Countries (CDC) of the [[European Mathematical Society]], AS-SMS was labeled “Emerging Regional Centre of Excellence of the European Mathematical Society” (ERCE) for the period of 2011-2015.<ref name="European Mathematical Society Website ">{{cite web | url=http://euro-math-soc.eu/EMS-CDC/erce.php | title=Emerging Regional Centre of Excellence | publisher=European Mathematical Society | accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref><ref name="Success Story of Higher Education Committee of Pakistan: ASSMS">{{cite web | url= http://www.hec.gov.pk/InsideHEC/Divisions/HRD/FacultyHiringPrograms/FFHP/Pages/ASSMS.aspx | title= Foreign Faculty Hiring Program: ASSMS | publisher= Higher Education Commission of Pakistan | accessdate=18 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304230457/http://www.hec.gov.pk/InsideHEC/Divisions/HRD/FacultyHiringPrograms/FFHP/Pages/ASSMS.aspx |archivedate=March 4, 2016}}</ref> Furthermore, AS-SMS and some other ERCE have form Network of International Mathematics Centres in 2013, where ASSMS was supposed to be its initial secretariat.<ref name="Network of International Mathematic Centres">{{cite web | url= http://www.mathunion.org/fileadmin/CDC/cdc-uploads/CDC_MENAO/nim-icm14.pdf | title= Network of International Mathematic Centres |publisher=The International Mathematical Union | accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref>
At the high school level, the school initiated the training camps for preparation and selection of the national team of Pakistan to compete at the [[International Mathematical Olympiad]] (IMO). The school continued to organize these training camps until 2014. The national team of Pakistan competed at IMO for the very first time in 2005, won its first medal in 2007 and its first silver medal in 2013.<ref name="International Mathematical Olympiad Official Site ">{{cite web | url=https://www.imo-official.org/country_team_r.aspx?code=PAK | title=Pakistan Results in IMO | publisher=International Mathematics Olympiad | accessdate=17 August 2015}}</ref>

The '''Arts Olympiad''' is an international art competition for children ages 8 to 12 organized by [[International Child Art Foundation]] with one million participants from seventy countries. Each competition is four years long and it is held every four year. The competition includes the element of art and peace to encourage children around the world to use creativity and cooperation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Promising Practices - Arts Olympiad|url=http://www.arizonahealthmatters.org/modules.php?op=modload&name=PromisePractice&file=promisePractice&pid=769|publisher=The Healthy Communities Institute|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref>
==History== Dr. Ashfaq Ishaq, founder of the International Child Art Foundation, started the first Arts Olympiad competition in 1999<ref name="1st-ao">{{cite web|title=1st Arts Olympiad (1997-2000)|url=http://www.icaf.org/whatwedo/ao/1st-ao.php|publisher=International Child Art Foundation|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref> to address the issue which was coined decades earlier as the "fourth grade slump" in creativity.<ref>{{cite book|last=Torrance|first=Ellis Paul|title=Understanding the fourth grade slump in creative thinking: final report|year=1967|publisher=University of Minnesota|pages=316}}</ref> The researchers at the time suggested that the phenomenon is a result of a drop in creativity around the ages of nine as they start conforming to [[standardized test]]ing and to please parents and teachers. The plan was to let children who were the winners of [[U.S. state]]s and other countries to come together in a festival to let them work together and learn other cultures with the goal to move future generations toward [[World peace|global peace]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Collins|first=Jane Hess|title=Get Out and Give Back: World Children’s Festival|url=http://www.washingtonlife.com/2011/06/13/get-out-and-give-back-world-children%E2%80%99s-festival/|accessdate=8 January 2013|newspaper=Washington Life Magazine|date=13 June 2011}}</ref>
The theme for the first Art Olympiad was ''My World in the Year 2000'' to ask children to create art in which they envisioned themselves in the [[new millennium]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Future Of Peace: Art By Young People|url=http://go.worldbank.org/HE9OOAUR30|publisher=The World Bank Group|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref> There was one million children in 86 countries in the program which was run between 1997 and 2000. The winning pieced from around the world were exhibited at the ''World Children’s Festival'' in 1999 on the [[National Mall]] in [[Washington, DC]]. The artworks were also later exhibited at the [[White House Millennium Council#White House Millennium Celebration|White House Millennium Celebration]], the [[United Nations Headquarters]], and the 2003 [[Annual Meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank Group|World Bank/IMF Annual Meetings]] in [[Dubai]].<ref name="1st-ao"/>
Since then the format of the global competition, a festival in Washington, DC and global exhibitions have been following in the next Arts Olympiad cycles. The 2nd Arts Olympiad was held between 2001 and 2004 with the theme of ''Me in the New Millennium''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dally|first=Ashley|title=Me in the New Millennium.(Perspective)(ICAF's 2000-2004 Arts Olympiad)|journal=ChildArt|date=1 April 2003|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-140305540.html|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref> Starting in the 3rd Arts Olympiad (2005-2008), the theme was shifted to relate art and sport<ref>{{cite web|title=Culture of Peace Project and Resources: Arts Olympiad|url=http://www3.unesco.org/iycp/uk/uk_visu_projet.asp?Proj=00087|publisher=International Year for the Culture of Peace - Unesco|accessdate=8 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707045049/http://www3.unesco.org/iycp/uk/uk_visu_projet.asp?Proj=00087#|archive-date=2010-07-07|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> to promote the artist-athlete ideal.<ref>{{cite web|title=The President's Challenge / About / Advocates / Nonprofit|url=https://www.presidentschallenge.org/about/advocates/nonprofit.shtml|publisher=The President’s Council on Fitness, Sports & Nutrition|accessdate=8 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025013502/https://www.presidentschallenge.org/about/advocates/nonprofit.shtml#|archive-date=2012-10-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The fourth Arts Olympiad (2009-2012) continued the same theme with title ''My Favorite Sport''.<ref>{{cite web|title=NCAC Partners International Child Art Foundation(ICAF) |url=http://www.ncac.gov.ng/ncacicf.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130222172708/http://www.ncac.gov.ng/ncacicf.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 February 2013 |publisher=National Council for Arts & Culture, Nigeria |accessdate=8 January 2013 }}</ref>
==Selection Process== During the first two years of the competition, local schools are participated in the Arts Olympiad lesson plan. The artworks as the result of the lessons are then put into a selection process.
The selection process in the United States is first done from at the local [[school district]]. The selection of artworks from within a school or school district. The artworks are then submitted to Washington, DC for another selection to have a representative of each participating state.<ref>{{cite news|title=Berwick Academy selected to represent Maine at World Children's Festival|url=http://www.fosters.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110311/GJNEWS_01/703119949&template=SouthernMaineRegion|accessdate=8 January 2013|newspaper=Fosters Daily Democrat|date=11 March 2011}}</ref>
In other countries, the partner in each country will administrate the selection. The selection can be in many phases involving the competition at the local level and at the national level.<ref>{{cite news|title=150 in Arts Olympiad|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2006/1/3/central/13010258&sec=central|accessdate=8 January 2013|newspaper=The Star Online|date=3 January 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Gana niño mazatleco Olimpiada del Arte a nivel nacional|url=http://www.noroeste.com.mx/publicaciones.php?id=660595&id_seccion=84363|accessdate=8 January 2013|newspaper=Noroeste.com|date=10 February 2011}}</ref>
The winners who represent the participating U.S. states and countries are invited to the World Children's Festival in Washington, DC.
==World Children's Festival== The World Children's Festival is a three-day festival held every four years on the National Mall in Washington, DC for winners of the Arts Olympiad to participate. The festival includes over 50 performances and many art-related workshops. It also has sessions for the winners from different countries to co-create artworks with many adult artists.<ref name="south-south">{{cite news|last=Jordan |first=Richard |title=4th World Children's Festival Held at the National Mall in Washington, DC |url=http://www.southsouthnews.com/pages/NewsDetails.aspx?NewsId=c45230b5-620e-4126-9bfe-9bcfca02812b |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714104844/http://www.southsouthnews.com/pages/NewsDetails.aspx?NewsId=c45230b5-620e-4126-9bfe-9bcfca02812b |dead-url=yes |archive-date=14 July 2011 |accessdate=8 January 2013 |newspaper=South-South News |date=22 June 2011 }}</ref>
Before the event, the Arts Olympiad winners from Washington, D.C. are asked to be ambassadors for the festival and exchange emails with international winners to welcome to the festival.<ref>{{cite web|title=The World Children's Festival|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/gog/misc-events/the-world-childrens-festival,1209274/critic-review.html|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=30 December 2012}}</ref> The international winners are welcomed to the host families around the Washington area.
Children share ideas and work together during the three-day festival. On the last night of the festival, the celebratory dinner is held with all guests dressing in [[Folk costume|national attire]].<ref name="south-south"/>
Similar festivals have been replicated in other counties such as the European Children’s Festival at Olympia Park in Munich in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|title=Founder of World’s Largest Art Program for Children Earns The Academy’s Distinguished Service Award|url=http://ussa.edu/publications/news/2011/10/27/founder-of-worlds-largest-art-program-for-children-earns-the-academys-distinguished-service-award/|publisher=United States Sports Academy|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref>
==International Exhibitions== After the World Children's Festival, the winning pieces will travel to exhibitions in the U.S. and internationally. The past exhibitions have been in [[United Arab Emirates]], [[Germany]], [[Israel]], [[South Korea]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Japan]], [[Uganda]], [[Italy]], [[Egypt]], [[Switzerland]], [[United Kingdom]], and [[Qatar]].<ref>{{cite web|title=ICAF Exhibitions 1998-2011|url=http://icaf.org/pdfs/ICAF%20Exhibitions%201998-2011.pdf|publisher=International Child Art Foundation|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref>
==Roles of Winners== The organizer have seen the potential and the importance of Art Olympiad winners to promote the cause. An example was demonstrated when a winner from [[Peru]] who have gone through difficulties in arranging competition because there was no office of the Internal Child Art Foundation in the country, that child eventually set up and organize the competition in the country for the next season with the support from the [[Ministry of Education (Peru)|ministry of education]]. With that, they started encouraging the winners to contribute back to the program and set up a youth board for the organization.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ashfaq Ishaq Discusses Challenges Faced Due To Lack of Arts Education |url=http://www.eclips.cornell.edu/clip.do?id=5127&clipID=5127&tab=TabClipPage |publisher=Charles H. Dyson School of Applied Economics and Management, Cornell University |accessdate=8 January 2013 |date=12 May 2004 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===Youth Board Members=== In each cycle of the Arts Olympiad competition, a number of winners are choose to serve the youth board of the organization. Their roles are to be organization's [[spokesperson]]s, conduct fundraising to support the programs, write for ChildArt magazine, help stage and be the [[master of ceremonies]] at the World Children's Festival, and nominate innovative leaders, companies and organizations for the World Children's Award.
Since the formation of the youth board there have been 38 members from two dozen counties.<ref>{{cite web|title=The ICAF Youth Board|url=http://www.icaf.org/about/youth.php|publisher=International Child Art Foundation|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref>
